B0006399FS|4.0|I have to say I'm shocked by the number of people who were so quick to rip apart this latest offering from the greatest active band on the planet, U2.  I'm even more astonished by how many reviewers cannot get past the fact that U2 had the audacity to sound a lot like U2 on this album.  Admittedly, HTDAAB isn't quite up to the ridiculous standards of the Joshua Tree, the Unforgettable Fire, or Achtung Baby for that matter.  But it is another dynamically consistent and satisfying collection of well-crafted and passionate music from a band that's been around longer than most of its reviewers apparently have.      Not that I think any excuses need to be made for this album, but, my message to those who can't accept it at face value because they've obviously set their expectations way too high would be this: Keep in mind that Bono, the Edge, Larry, and Adam are all into their forties at this point.  As we all know, rock and roll was, is and always will be, in essence, a young man's game.  Even still, they are clearly demolishing the majority of bands who are only half their age at it.  And, for a point of reference, need I remind you of what the Rolling Stones were giving us when its members were around the same age that U2's is?  Dirty Work, anyone?  Or who could forget Paul McCartney's effort released when he was 43, Press to Play?  The Kinks were releasing their best album ever with Word of Mouth.  And, yes, Pete Townshend's Iron Man: A Musical was clearly on the same level as the Who's Tommy.  Or not. The point being: Knowing what history has shown we could be getting from U2 at this stage in their career, why are we pounding on them for releasing something THIS good?    Call me crazy, but I still get chills from hearing the combination of Edge's trademark delayed guitar, Adam's steady bass playing, and Larry's thunderous drumming.  Plus, there are few singers in this world with a voice as distinctive and powerful as Bono's - even if it's starting to show a little wear and tear.  Why wouldn't they want to capitalize and showcase these key elements of their sound, instead of burying them like they did on the lifeless and passion-less mess called Pop?  After all, this is a sound that they themselves created.  Do you really need to hear the songs embellished with drum samples and meaningless studio wizardry to make this a more acceptable and less snicker-worthy release?  Must they completely re-invent the wheel on each outing?  Or maybe if the album turned out to be a colossal commercial disappointment and didn't have the iPod connection, it would finally be embraced by serious and \\"hip\\" music fans everywhere as their \\"unheralded masterpiece\\".    The bottom line:  This is a startingly good record...ESPECIALLY for a band that's been at it as long as U2 has.  No, it isn't without a couple missteps, but the majority of the songs on HTDAAB are everything that we've come to expect and crave from U2:  Dripping with emotion, unforgettable, and packed with gigantic hooks.  \\"City of Blinding Lights\\", in my opinion, may even be among the best songs U2 has ever written.  As for the lyrics on HTDAAB, some of them can be embarrassing...but Bono has always been one to make us scratch our heads and say \\"huh?\\" from time to time.  Still, taken as a whole, HTDAAB is capable of creating the same eerie and atmospheric quality that albums like Unforgettable Fire and Boy had.  It can rock like Achtung Baby did.  And, it can produce lumps in your throat like Joshua Tree did.  For me, that's more than enough.      Don't convice yourself that you couldn't possibly find the room in your heart to enjoy this album; give it a good, honest listen.  You'll be pleasantly surprised with what you find.
0780622545|2.0|This movie has a good premise and an excellent set, but crappy writing! There's no story development. Everything we need to know is told in short bursts. I was annoyed because the movie unfolded without rhyme or reason. The movie felt more like a trailer. And the acting... Sutherland was totally miscast as the scientist. He seemed to be hyperventilating everytime he spoke. \\"The strangers\\" sounded like they ripped off their vocals from The Exorcist. Over-acted and over-rated, that sums it up!  <br />     <br /> <br />
